author: mike.ferris
content:
<@!364458974906548225> Very clear document, thank you! I have two related questions:
- could the accumulator root eventually be added to the block header? Or is there a reason that would never happen? 
- did the Alexandria POC ever implement any accumulator functionality? It doesn't seem to, based off searching "accumulator" etc in what I think is the most recent version:  https://github.com/ethereum/ddht/tree/master/ddht/v5_1/alexandria

author: pipermerriam
content:
1: there is nothing keeping it out of the block header other than the overhead of getting it through the eip process and implemented in the clients. We should try to make this happen in the next hard fork but it might be a hard sell.

2: yes, it was implemented. Probably in a branch on my  fork of the ddht/Alexandria python code. I'm on my phone so I can't dig it up right now. I'll try to remember to give it for you.

author: mike.ferris
content: great, thanks! I'll remind you on the CDAP call tomorrow. Random question: why do a lot of your commits to the ddht and alexandria repos only have the commit message "d"?

author: pipermerriam
content: so the commit message "d".  is short for "dirty" which is me committing work that doesn't fall into a clean commit.  When I'm in "figure it out" mode, I pile these up, and once I've got things worked out, I rebase them all away into well contained logical commits....  except that alexandria and ddht were proof-of-concepts and I was working "fast and loose" to just hammer out the functionality that I was experimenting with, so that later step of rebasing and cleaning up stopped happening, and even the code review stopped happening....
